From the Leader, Sept. 27.

Wagons loaded of citizens have been bought in Madeko at least from three to seven times their present value.

Nearly fifty delegates have signified their willingness to attend the Agreed at Corunna meeting, and there are expected to respond favorably.

Sheriff Root, of Fargo County, who was present, said the money was the most wanted in the county by far.

Four hundred ballots were cast; the year's tax was 3 per cent, and the proposed new scheme was already delivered at the barracks.

From the Journal, Sept. 29.

The election returns presented by the Assiniboia Agricultural Society are attractive, and attention is asked east and west on this line, as the results will be brought to town next week.

Five hundred dollars worth of wheat this year's crop on a spring plow will be delivered already delivered at the barracks.

From the Leader, Sept. 27.

The fall round-up is going on in the cattle district. It was reported last Thursday that there were thirty-eight cows killed at Packer's camp on the banks of Chateau river.

A party of policemen was out doing Sunday night looking for whisky. They discovered a grog-shop in the same locality.

Another Roman Catholic Bishop is likely to be appointed to assist His Lordship Bishop Grondin. It is not known as yet who the new Bishop will be.

Recked in at last to save a run mill.

In town superintending the erection of it. The house was being sold yesterday.

On Saturday last the members of the Roman Catholic Church of Indiana were particularly interested in the work of the press. Basil Shield, a member of the Board, examined some newspapers critically, and stated that although they thought of the whole thing, he said that he thought that the whites were the best of the Indians living in the territory.

One or two days ago the Indians made an attempt to go out to work and run a newspaper for them on the Goulter farm.

The question on the border in full force. The regulations are in brief as follows: Horses, mules, sheep and hogs may be purchased locally; those found without local supplies must be destroyed immediately if they have been shipped into the state.

They must keep their animals and fowl quarantined at all times.

Eskimos were taxed for the first time.

A lot of people on the boat from Harriswood said they would never vote for Mr. Britton again.

EDMONTON.

From the Bulletin, Sept. 17.

Mr. Macdonald has been remembered for a brief biography in the Bulletin, which appeared in the morning edition of the Bulletin.

The District of Alberta has been constituted by the Grand Lodge of Catholics.

Geo. Longt of the Starlight, shows an excellent sample of red fire wheat, which he has five acres entirely under cultivation.

Work is being pushed on the Alberta lumber company's mill at Red Deer, giving employment to the settlers in the surrounding district.

D. Ross of the Elmendorf Hamlet has met with success from the beginning of the season for his market garden, which measure five acres under cultivation and are well filled.

The agricultural exchange and trading school at Medicine Hat, has now once again been opened, and quite a number of persons have attended.

J. D. Hutchison lately cut a field of oats, and so tall that the harvest絺eeder could not reach it, near the top of the grain and requires that the thresher be sent to aid him, as he could not get it off even with the most powerful draft, as he had but two horses and the manure was very high.

Africa. From the News, Sept. 28.

Work has been commenced on the new Presbyterian manse. The foundation was laid about two weeks ago, and the contractor is only waiting for the builder to be able to proceed with the work.

The fall round-up is going on in the North-West Territories. Work on the railway cannot be started until the spring, owing to the intense cold.

WEST YOKOTA.

Mr. B. M. Collins, storekeeper.

Moore & Macdowell requested to engage the services of a young farmer for the purpose of learning the business in his store.

Mr. Geo. Callaghan came down from Macleod on Saturday evening and will be here soon to take the vacancy left by Mr. Adamson, who leaves for California shortly.

Col. and Mrs. Macleod arrived from Macleod where they have been spending their vacations so far, Monday evening's train. They went up to Macleod on Wednesday.

MACLEOD.

At the request of a number of influential citizens of the district, I have decided, on the advice of my friend Mr. James McEachran, to commence at once the publication throughout the district of a list containing the names and addresses of all those who have been employed in the recent war by the United States government.

At the request of a number of influential citizens of the district, I have decided, on the advice of my friend Mr. James McEachran, to commence at once the publication throughout the district of a list containing the names and addresses of all those who have been employed in the recent war by the United States government.

$25 per annum
